sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Acromegaly, Second-line therapy: loading dose, 40 mg SUBQ once; administer under physician supervision
  • Acromegaly, Second-line therapy: maintenance, 10 mg SUBQ once daily; adjust dose in 5-mg increments based on serum insulin-like growth factor (IGF-I) levels; MAX dose is 30 mg/day

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and effectiveness have not been established in children

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• hepatic impairment (baseline): liver function tests greater than 3 times the upper limit of normal, do not begin therapy until a comprehensive workup determines the cause of liver dysfunction
  • hepatic impairment (during therapy): liver function tests greater than or equal to 3 times the upper limit of normal (ULN) but less than 5 times the ULN, continue therapy but perform a comprehensive workup to determine the cause of liver dysfunction
  • hepatic impairment (during therapy): liver function tests (LFT) at least 5 times the upper limit of normal (ULN) or AST/ALT at least 3 times the ULN with any increase in serum total bilirubin, discontinue therapy and perform a comprehensive workup (eg, serial LFT) to determine the cause of liver dysfunction; if LFT normalize, may restart therapy
  • hepatic impairment (during therapy): signs and symptoms of hepatitis or other liver injury (eg, jaundice, bilirubinuria, right upper quadrant pain), perform a comprehensive workup and discontinue therapy if liver injury is confirmed

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• concomitant use with a somatostatin analogue (octreotide acetate) (unapproved use); increased risk of marked hepatic enzyme elevations (greater than 10 times the ULN)
  • cross-reactivity with growth hormone assays may occur
  • diabetes mellitus; glucose tolerance may improve; monitoring recommended
  • functional growth hormone deficiency may occur; monitoring recommended
  • growth hormone-secreting tumors; may expand during treatment; monitoring recommended
  • hypersensitivity reactions, systemic, have been reported (eg, anaphylactic/anaphylactoid reactions, laryngospasm, angioedema); some patients required hospitalization; monitoring recommended if re-initiating therapy in patients with systemic hypersensitivity reaction
  • lipohypertrophy has been reported; rotate injection sites daily
  • liver enzyme elevations have been reported; monitoring recommended; therapy interruption or discontinuation may be necessary
  • liver test baseline levels greater than 3 times ULN; use not recommended until cause is identified; monitoring recommended
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Injection site reaction (4% to 11%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (0% to 14%), Nausea (0% to 14%)
  • Other:Infectious disease (Infection, 0% to 23%), Influenza-like illness (4% to 12%), Pain (4% to 14%)
Serious
  • Hepatic:Liver function tests abnormal (4% to 12%; greater than 10 to 15 times ULN, 0.8% to 2%)
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Other:Anaphylactoid reaction

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Pegvisomant is a recombinant growth hormone-receptor antagonist which selectively binds to the growth hormone (GH) receptors on the cell surface. By blocking the binding of endogenous GH, pegvisomant causes a decrease in serum concentrations of insulin-like growth hormone (IGF-I), IGF-binding protein -3, and the acid-labile subunit.

0.title: Absorption
0.mono:
• Bioavailability: (subcutaneous), 57% (for a 20-mg subcutaneous dose relative to a 10-mg IV dose)
  • Tmax: (subcutaneous), 33 to 77 hr

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Renal: (subcutaneous), less than 1% recovered in urine over 96 hr
  • Total body: (subcutaneous), 28 to 36 mL/hr

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Subcutaneous
  • reconstitute with Sterile Water for Injection, USP; do not shake vial
  • use only 1 dose per vial
  • use within 6 hr of reconstitution
  • administer subcutaneously in the thigh, buttocks, upper arm, or abdomen; rotate injection sites daily

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• serum insulin-like growth-hormone (IGF-I) levels; at 4-6 weeks after initiating or changing therapy and at least every 6 months after IGF-I levels have normalized
  • control of acromegaly signs and symptoms
  • liver function tests (eg, AST, AST, total bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase); at baseline; if levels normal, obtain levels monthly during first 6 months, quarterly for next 6 months, and biannually for the next year; if baseline levels are less than or equal to 3 times upper limit of normal (ULN), obtain levels monthly for at least 1 year and then biannually for the next year; if baseline levels are greater than 3 times ULN, close monitoring required if treatment is initiated
  • abnormal liver function tests (LFT) during treatment; if levels greater or equal to 3 times the upper limit of normal (ULN) but less than 5 times the ULN, obtain LFTs weekly; if levels at least 5 times ULN or transaminase level at least 3 times ULN with any increase in serum total bilirubin, discontinue therapy and obtain LFTs frequently if therapy is reinitiated
  • signs or symptoms of liver dysfunction
  • signs and symptoms of growth-hormone deficiency
  • diabetic patients: serum glucose and signs and symptoms of hypoglycemia
  • growth-hormone secreting tumors: imaging scans of the sella turcica periodically

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
Somavert
Subcutaneous Powder for Solution: 10 MG, 15 MG, 20 MG, 25 MG, 30 MG

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patient to report a latex sensitivity prior to administration, as vial stopper contains latex.
  • Drug may cause peripheral edema, pain, infection, flu-like symptoms, nausea, and diarrhea.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of hepatotoxicity (nausea, fatigue, jaundice, right upper quadrant tenderness).
  • Patients with diabetes mellitus should monitor for and report changes in glycemic control, as antidiabetic medication dosages may need to be adjusted.
  • Teach patient proper technique and placement of injections.
  • Advise patient to report use of opioid medicines, as dosage adjustment of pegvisomant may be required.
